subject: DOCKER-863: Create shared volume when mounting nonexistent volume DOCKER-881: docker start should provision shared volume only if required VOLAPI-26: wf-runner crashes with: Uncaught AssertionError: "string" == "object" VOLAPI-9 Implement asynchronous NFS
commitMessage:
DOCKER-863: Create shared volume when mounting nonexistent volume
DOCKER-881: docker start should provision shared volume only if required
VOLAPI-26: wf-runner crashes with: Uncaught AssertionError: "string" == "object"
VOLAPI-9 Implement asynchronous NFS shared volume creation
VOLAPI-6: Deleting a tritonnfs volume used by an active Docker container should fail
VOLAPI-27 Divergence in `docker create -v` behavior; volume is not created until `docker start`
VOLAPI-54 Custom errors' rest codes should follow engineering guide's guidelines
VOLAPI-55 After enabling volapi, a sdcadm update without volapi fails
DOCKER-1034 support docker volume ls -f dangling=true
VOLAPI-65 rename required_nfs_volumes VM objects' property to volumes
TOOLS-1830 replace sdcadm experimental nfs-volumes with cloudapi-nfs-volumes/docker-nfs-volumes subcommands
ZAPI-796 NFS volumes provisioning tasks chain broken by switch from node-uuid to uuid module in sdc-workflow
DOCKER-1088 sdc-docker should not modify VMs' internal docker:nfsvolumes metadata
PUBAPI-1420 Add ability to mount NFS volumes with CreateMachine endpoint
ZAPI-794 remove_volume_references task in destroy workflow should not error

Patch Set 14:

Testing notes: I ran all the CloudAPI and sdc-docker volume related tests with those changes in my COAL and they all passed.

I also ran the full VMAPI tests suite with no VOLAPI service setup in nightly-1 and they all passed.
Change has been successfully merged by Julien Gilli
Errr ... shouldn't be "options.re.test(value)"? Otherwise this is hardcoded to the VOLUME_NAME_RE constant despite of what you pass to the function.

Yes it should, good catch, will fix!

This whole block is also a leftover from a now irrelevant change, so I'll drop that entirely.

In case we get an error from vmapi.getVm, shouldn't we return this callback(err) call before we go through all this process? I'm thinking that waiting to this point to call the callback with an hypothetical error could means that we'll never reach this point b/c on the cases where we have such error, we don't get a "vm" and would be returning ```new Error('Could not get VM with uuid ' + vmUuid)``` and hiding the cause for the lack of such value.
I'd personally go with at least "7.6.0" if not "8.0.0". Not a tiny change, though
Sounds good, I'll update to 8.0.0 even if it seems it doesn't really matter today because we use checksums to determine whether the workflow code changed?
Is VError accessible from inside workflows? I cant find any previous examples, but if so, it would be nice to use it here.
Good point, I believe verror is available from workflow jobs. Will fix.

Should this maybe be:


    'workflow/' + job.name

(Or is this already a convention?)
No convention I'm aware of, I like your suggestion, so will change to that.
If there's an error here, too, should we log it with job.log.error()?

This function itself doesn't send the request. The request is sent using "common.zoneAction". This block comment says below:

This function only sets the request up. The request is performed later by subsequent tasks in the same workflow. The next task with a body equal to 'common.zoneAction' sends the request, and the task after with a body of 'common.waitTask' waits for it to complete.

Is that too confusing?
Ah, I see. I was confused by the "Sets a request to CNAPI" phrasing. How about something like "Prepares a request to CNAPI"?
That sounds better indeed, will change!
It seems equivalent to what's currently here, or am I missing something?
I was thinking that it would help this function avoid calling Object.keys() twice. It's not a big deal, but it seemed like it would be better to do it only once.
Ah ok, yes that makes sense, will change!
Do you want to wrap this in a try/catch, and error out the workflow when nfsVolumesInternalMetadata contains a bad JSON string?
Yes, that's a good point. Will fix.
Move "moray" onto its own line for readability.
Move this return onto its own line, and remove the other two, to match the style in waitForValue()?
Yep, that's from code moved from somewhere else, but I'll take this opportunity to fix it.
Using split('-')[0] is more intuitive to me, but I understand it's subjective. I'd be happy to change it to your suggestion though if you can help me understand the benefits better.

I was mostly thinking that it should match how this is done below, like:

https://cr.joyent.us/#/c/2525/2/test/vms.volumes.test.js@176

I'd be fine with those being updated to match this, or all of them being updated to use a generateShortId() or similar helper function that makes it using either method.
That makes sense, I'll create a test/lib/uuid.js module that exports a generateShortId function and make those call sites use it.
Can we use the RegExp object defined on line 51 here?

Reading this makes me wonder: IIRC, VMs sometimes have their status changed to 'deleted' briefly by vm-agent when ops migrates VMs between CNs, but they then get updated to 'running' again once the migration finishes, since the vm-agent on the destination CN picks it up. Will that affect VOLAPI in some way? Should it wait some amount of time (10 minutes? an hour?) before assuming it's fully gone?

Great question!

We don't want to wait 10 minutes or an hour to consider a VM fully gone because we want to allow users to delete their volumes as soon as the latest VM that was mounting it is gone.

The VM migration use case is not covered currently. What would happen is that there would be a window of time when a VM being migrated would not reference the volumes it mounts, and in that window users could delete the volumes that this VM mounts.

If the volumes that VM mounts were deleted, then when the VM comes back, it would not be able to mount them.

If the volumes that VM mounts were not deleted, then when the VM comes back, a new reference from that VM to those volumes would be added and users would not be able to delete the volumes it mounts.

So I think this can be considered an edge case for the "master integration" milestone, but I'll create a ticket to track this.

Thoughts?

Ah, I misunderstood how the references worked. I'd thought that when the reference count dropped to 0, it was removed, but it sounds like it just allows the owner to then delete it through VOLAPI? In that case, this seems like an edge case that we don't need to worry about until we actually implement and support user-driven migrations in the product.
Do you need to add VError to the modules here, too?
Is the plan to do a new sdc-clients release at some point before integrating this CR, and then update to that version here?
Yes, I actually just released node-sdc-clients 10.4.0, I'll update this ref now.

I think it might be better to make this work like what we did in NAPI-387, and only skip these tests when something like VMAPITEST_SKIP_VOLUMES=true. Then we can set that in Jenkins for nightly2 or wherever we decide to skip them.

As discussed in private, this is not feasible currently since NFS volume support is not going to be enabled by default for at least a while. Once NFS volumes support is enabled by default, we'll definitely use a similar technique  to what NAPI uses.
